It’s one of those podcasts that’s actually hard to listen to, because it neither offers much new nor presents it in a novel way (I realize the research is often new, but it’s not surprising). It’s the kind where you’re hoping for good back and forth but it’s really not that.

Like “finally someone is talking about the brain thing that I ruminated over when I was a kid! Wait, they’re missing this bit, and also it ties into this whole angle they’re ignoring and omg, they’re skipping these implications entirely.”

The thing I both hate and love about hidden brain (podcast) is it’s mostly articulating brain hacks of my weird childhood. It’s simultaneously rather affirming (also some discomfort in that) and frustratingly simplistic/without much nuance in each take.

@AarneGranlund I'm very glad that you did survive, and were lucky enough to come out with backpack + all fingers too. May this close call be as close as you come to worse!
@advicepig I am getting very intrigued by this tiktok thing, mainly based on the transpo/walking stuff I've been hearing about it!

@AarneGranlund I know that your experiences are in a rural setting (vs mine in a city but in that video), I feel the kinship of being out in the deep cold (+ when it's getting towards -25C before windchill, I stop running into other people). Solidarity in the life of winter to you, friend!

Of course, this was twenty years ago, with less frequent freeze/thaw. And this was one particular sidewalk. And it was only about 1/3 the panels of that short stretch of sidewalk, with two different topographies (one low point didn't always flood).
@advicepig I would love to! But I also feel like it's this glorious place-based knowledge, where each square of sidewalk is its own unique creature to learn and care for.

The wide push broom is to move water off your sidewalks into the street on v melty days. It's exactly as slow as you might expect sweeping water to be, but also more effective than just a scoop-shovel to get rid of most of it. 

When you've got most of it, you sprinkle some sand

I also learned that you need tools + skills + specialized knowledge, some of which I rarely see employed today. 

You need your shovel, yes, but also your ice chipper and (the one I almost never see) your wide push broom.

I grew up in the extended family home, with sidewalk winter care modeled by the generations older than me. I learnt shoveling is your fundamental duty to your neighbors, which also means you're out before the snow ends because they rely on the transportation network you maintain.

In my observation, this is a bit more common on sidewalks on the south side of streets, where that bright sun on the roof/blvd creates lots of melt flowing to the sidewalk, but the shade gets it to sheer black ice fairly reliably.

Say you're a property owner, one of the tip-top shovelers (thank you!). You're out clearing as soon as the snow falls until it ends. You have no car curb cuts. And yet your sidewalk often becomes dangerously icy, sometimes even worse than your degenerate never-shovels neighbor's.

I'm not convinced it was a good solution regardless, but at this point, we're essentially creating sidewalk canals (or moats or long lakes?), bounded on either side by frozen and/or fully saturated soil trapped beneath walls of packed snow/ice. 

That's...not pedestrian friendly.

But Mpls' winter climate is and has been shifting rapidly with climate breakdown. Whereas before, things got v cold and stayed v cold for most of the winter, now we're warmer, with more frequent freeze/thaw cycles, more days with sun causing snow to melt, night freezing into ice.

The thinking is this: The snow falls on buildings + yards + parking lots. When it melts, we want as little as possible to flow into our storm drains. Instead, our hope is that slowing the water before it reaches the drains allows more to filter thru the blvd into groundwater.

A huge % of ice/snow melt on most surfaces in the city (besides parks/water/street/, ~2' of blvd) flows onto the sidewalk. And the sidewalk, unlike our stormwater/sewer systems, is designed not to move water, but as part of a system to slow/hold water to reduce stormwater runoff

The 2nd re-deposit issue is related to the city's drainage regulations for stormwater management (across the sidewalk to get to the storm drain in hopes of infiltrating the soil) & the engineering flaw in how our sidewalks are designed (i.e. without regard to winter drainage).

Like, where I could feel, while walking through the puddle, a first sinking and then a second sinking. Very very impressive, wish I could've captured the feeling somehow!

Since I'm getting some retweets, just want to be explicit that this is from 3/13/19, but the conditions shown are parallel to what I was coming across walking last Saturday on 3/12/22, so it's at least representative and sadly far from irrelevant.

This happens all the time in Special Service Districts (on car-centric community corridors currently clogged with parking lots), which are held up as a model for municipal clearance. I'm not sure if any SSD has re-clearance of these areas included within any of their contracts.

Firstly, we've got the sibling to windrows: car-droppings. Wherever cars go, they continuously redeposit or push around snow/ice, often in forms (chunks, slick dangerous ice) that're way harder to clear than just snow. 

This happens at every curbcut, alleyway, and intersection.

Sidewalks also face two HUGE sources of snow/ice redeposit that can occur days and even weeks after the last precipitation event. 

(All the sidewalk snow clearance regs I've seen are written exclusively for immediately post-precipitation-event, not for re-deposit)

Those ^ (impervious surface drainage regulation, plowing patterns, snow/ice clearance training) are just the issues most directly caused by city policies and procedures (not engineering or land use planning).

I've come across sidewalks made impassable because city crews clearing storm drains piled a huge volume of snow onto the sidewalk adjacent. 

Some plow drivers legit seem to think bus stops are actually excess snow-deposits. 

We've got some major work to do in training folks.

Additionally, some subsets of city programs will do targeted sidewalk blocking. For example, I've got video of a city plow blocking in a beautifully cleared curbcut with snow that had been in the middle of the street.

But even beyond that, city/county snow clearing procedures are a huge problem. They create impassable windrows at virtually every bus stop & street/alley intersection sometimes days after snowfall. They plow/spray snow onto cleared sidewalks on streets with minimal/no boulevards

The prime example of this is the sheer number of properties with gutters that drain directly (functionally) onto the sidewalk. This includes downspouts that end on concrete 10+ feet away or gutters running to 2' from the property line. 

This is by design in Mpls city regulations

It's not just the right tools. Streets are designed to drain, not be drained onto, so they only infrequently need clearing attention between precip events. Sidewalks, in contrast, have different ice/snow re-deposit events/risks depending on many factors

Walking means finding a dumpster full of the disassembled shelves your friend needs for their workshop space. Walking means moving high-end curb-furniture a quarter block to a better visibility corner.

Walking means unplanned and chance encounters, running into friends who're in town for the weekend, making plans with someone you've been meaning to call, finding out who's out of the hospital from a mutual who's got you on the list of who to update.

Walking means knowing at least some of our neighbors who're unhoused or sleeping rough. Walking means community + chatting, asking what they need, defending them against gossips and bullies, looking out for each other.

Walking is kicking a drainage channel open before the giant puddle refreezes. Walking is jump-kicking the leaves out of the storm drain so the puddle in front of the curb ramp can drain. Walking is telling store managers when their sidewalks/curb ramps are snowy/icy/dangerous.
@FireflyLake Exactly. Especially when the problem is, by and large, the choices the city makes with regards to drainage, stormwater management, engineering, and plowing
Walking is stomping down the fresh snow on the often-used desire line that'll never get shoveled, because you're in deep boots and know that others might not be.
Walking is playing crossing guard to the frogs leaping across the bike path, leaving your post only when an intrigued biker offers to take over for the last few.
Walking is pushing stuck drivers out of snow and uphill with other pedestrians, for hours.
Walking is offering a spare plastic bag to someone else caught by the unexpected rain, as you shelter under a little overhang together, to keep their phone dry as they head back into it.

Walking is flashing your hands at a (grateful!) driver whose lights aren't on, walking is shouting at and blocking a confused driver trying to turn the wrong way onto a one way, walking is letting a driver know their tire's fully flat.
Walking is letting a stranger use your phone, then walking a few blocks in the same direction while they use your battery to charge theirs up a bit.

Walking is being urgently asked for directions with a language barrier, and realizing that going together is the only option, and getting them checked in to the waiting room of the optical surgery unit of the hospital before a surprise (and welcome) hug as you leave

Walking is finding a credit card, finding its owner online, and dropping it off with their work before they're even back from their delivery route. Finding a wallet and returning it to their spouse working in the yard listed on the ID.

Walking is clearing debris out of the bike lane. Walking is dragging cones and signs and barrels off the sidewalk. Walking is marking sharp tripping hazards with cairns of nearby trash or twisting drooping chainlink fences back up so no one rides or walks into them at night.

Walking is pushing every beg button for the pedestrian who's coming after you. 

Walking is edging into the street until drivers have to notice you, because the more they see you, the more they see and are safe towards more vulnerable people walking/using wheelchairs.

Walking is knowing all the locations where your favorite street musicians play and aiming for them on a day when you've actually got cash. 

Walking is knowing what the streets sound like in each season, the intertwining melodies of wind and water and people and buildings.
Walking is playing a few rounds of silent smiling peekaboo with the alert baby grinning over the shoulder of the person carrying them ahead of you before you turn off down the next street.

@colocha_rachel <3 I know you know it intuitively. 

I think part of it is that a lot of it is so simple that it's hard to articulate. So much of what we need is each other, in infinite teensy tiny ways. And our culture really is about dismissing everything soft + singular + many-pieced + simple
@TallTeenTurtle SAME! So only mostly a joke. Also a cautionary tale for any who ever ask me to speak about winter walking/wheelchair infrastructure
Walking is getting happily waylaid for twenty minutes in a cold drizzle because you're chatting with a bike-scrapper/junker about your best curb finds and the bikes they fix and build.

Walking is the slightly-judgy person going the same direction on a sidewalk with you who asks why you're hustling so fast, and whose face lights up with an involuntary "oh yes!" when you both turn the corner to see the radiant sunset (that you were hustling to keep watching).

Walking is wondering how you're going to help your elderly father up from a stoop to hustle to shelter before the rain rolls over, and the man who's agitated on a phone call the whole time he smiles and gently/wordlessly helps him stand and get his balance back.

Walking is the bandaids in your purse when a child at the bus stop skins their knee. Walking is having an extra bottle of frozen water for the person signing on the corner. Walking is offering to share cold strawberries on a hot day with unsheltered neighbors on church steps.

Walking is spending an hour and a half talking with a very distressed older man who's just gotten terrible news about a family member, of being with him in and through the first flare of this burning grief.

Walking is the woman who sees the tears on your face as you hustle across the 10 lane crosswalk on your way to therapy during a winter of depression, and the eye contact she makes as she says, with care "it will get better."

Walking is finding a $10 bill frozen in an alley, and giving it a few hours later to a neighbor trying to find shelter after a particularly cold night. Walking is introducing yourselves when you meet, sharing resources, sharing information, sharing humanity & respect & care.

Walking is responding with an open heart to the conversation of a jaded young man who's dismissive of the dead bee you've stopped to notice, until he offers to bury it himself, picking it up and cradling its body so gently before heading the opposite way on the street again.

Walking is staying with a neighbor who's possibly overdosing, calling 911 and being present with them until EMS arrives. 

Walking is offering to take a family photo for a parent trying to corral her three impatient tweens on an outing.

Walking is knowing a place. Walking is knowing people. Walking is knowing what community feels like. Walking is being able to read an aggregate mood and respond. Walking is being there for a neighbor in crisis. Walking is being there to share in a strangers' joy.

It's radical.

Anyone who walks/uses wheelchairs for transportation + pleasure in a city knows we are community, we are mutual aid, we are here for one another.

You just cannot be in community from a car. It's a tool to some ends sometimes, but it's not inherent or default community-building.

Walking/using wheelchairs more increases safety and security especially for those who are most vulnerable, in real and material ways, unlike policing/surveillance state choices. 

Walking increases independence for marginalized while knitting us together in interdependence.

One of the most radical acts you can do, at any place and time, is walk/use wheelchairs more, especially as transportation. 

Walking is inherently generative. The more people are out, the more comfortable others are being out. Walking builds + strengthens community/connections.

So many ways to do this! It's one of my favs, can be <60 seconds or a new habit you institute, and can scale up or help move you towards other changes. 

Other car-based ideas:
Park 18+" from the curb to narrow the street/slow drivers.
Stop at red lights.

But that's itself a risk, tricking us into science denial and delay of action

Another part of what's intriguing me is the way that actually facing climate breakdown does and will overlap with many cult narratives in both positive/negative ways (eg this being a time for us all to step up to "save humanity" and also apocalyptic possibilities)

I'm so grateful for all of you who ARE out, but because we're all still in this cult and trying to survive in it/get others out, it's also really hard to recognize each other, to speak freely with one another, and to not default into from the thought-limiting cult thinking

One of the things drawing my attention to cults right now is trying to understand how to survive/function (emotionally, mentally, socially, psychically) when you're forced to live inside the cult and there isn't an "out" yet to escape to or calibrate from.

It's a fundamentally extremely disconcerting feeling, and I know many more (but not all) of you can relate now, in the pandemic and having been through different stages of community response. And of course, it's not a disconnect/dis-ease triggered by covid or climate.

That's kinda how I've felt about 99% of conversations/settings for the last decade plus. 

The collective silence around what covid/climate means for any particular topic/group is EXTREMELY DISTRESSING. Often it's not in the moment (emotional social norming dampens it) but after

How would you have felt, prevaccine, if your workplaces, if your social circles, if your kids' schools or your doctor's offices were all communicating the day to day to you as if they were in 2019? No talk of masks or ventilation or even the irrelevant handwipes + shields?

Or perhaps covid is a better analogy. At least for a while, the majority of my circles were talking about it in actual real terms (as we should be with climate). We didn't pretend it was something external to how we live our lives or the choices we make. We were disrupted by it.

In the day-to-day, I keep finding that triage is taking my time + attention. We need everyone to be integrating climate-context into every conversation--I personally need that

Rn in most settings, I still feel like I'm the only one aware of/changing that dirty diaper.

We're making progress, for sure. In the last two years, I've at time known more real hope than at any other point in the last twenty. I feel like I can finally see--in increasingly real ways--where and how I could bring my core self to climate justice in meaningful/useful ways

@snacklesbian @EcoAnxiousCa Absolutely so so up for this sharing/support/venting in just about whatever way makes sense to you. (Caveat: texting is my worst/least reliable comms currently, phone is best, and I also slip into positive-slant scripts very easily with almost everything climate-tangential)

Those things you see in me that are just...too much, clumsy, bellicose? 

A lot of it is because I'm outside that core self. It's not inherently regenerative or energizing or fulfilling for me. It's fear/trauma-based, and while I can learn/do it cognitively, it's not intuitive.

It wasn't the enneagram that allowed me to see this but conversations with/observing people who are ACTUALLY truly internally motivated by principles, purpose, and perfectionism. There's a process difference when that framework is innate, rather than created as a trauma response.

Really. We need everyone, the wide range of skills + care + love that each of us has. I need you.

That childhood-trauma-response self of mine, that ethical compass set to red-alert "not in my name, not on my watch"? It motivates me, but doesn't fulfill me. At best, some relief.

Look at me. I'm flighty, painfully optimistic/cheerful, creative, ornery, distractable, spontaneous, gregarious, forgetful, dreamy, novelty-driven. My whole ethos necessitating 100% attention to climate justice is a childhood trauma add-on to my base personality.

How do you integrate our climate reality and both its requisite response (emissions reductions, resiliency) and impacts (systems instability, collapse) into every conversation so the burden is actually shared?

I haaaaaate when people judge other people’s grief (inc anyone not responding as they are). You can mourn the death of an abuser you also hated. You can feel relief at someone’s death whom you loved deeply. Or feel untouched. They’re feelings, you’re human, it’s not predictable.

And also grief in death is just a fucking mindfuck on top of the complexity of being human + every other relationship state. So I am zero judgments about how you do or don’t feel now vs then or whatever. Your grief is yours however it manifests, even relief/celebration, no shame.

But I know that in the US, a lot of people completely to talk about dead people, and to keep talking about dead people because we don’t forget the ones we love. So that’s my little goal, to show I’m comfortable meeting them through you, if you would like.

I don’t know how I want people to be when I’m grieving. It has been very varied. Sometimes I want tight hugs from strangers only. Sometimes I want to run and run and run. Sometimes I don’t want anyone to see me cry.

So what I want doesn’t seem any sort of useful guide.

I’ve thought hard about how to try to be there for 💔 others. 

My go to in non-immediate-grief settings where i sense a little rawness is to ask, with respect/zero pressure, for a little about their loved one. Even just a name. To show space if wanted to talk about beloved dead https://t.co/rxYVPQ6KTq

Lookin at human societies/culture/history, this way of doing things--creating urban spaces that're low-density sprawl, require immense energy to heat/cool/move around, and are almost wholly without any food growing--is the increasingly dangerous anomaly.

Human food production has historically included at least some within the borders of densely populated spaces. Some historic cities have deeply integrated food production (to the extent that it shows up on LIDAR and in plant patterns hundreds of years later).

Luckily (as with so many other issues) what we need to do to adapt our food sourcing + ag culture and turn ourselves to mending this world/our systems in the face of spiraling climate breakdown allows for/encourages multi-solving.

When we talk about the implications of climate breakdown--that everything must change--that includes how we live and how we eat. 

It isn't ok to default to:
Daily meat/dairy 
Access to any food any time shipped via reefer planes/trucks
Single use packaging

The ways we produce food right now are just terrifying, frankly, by so many measures beyond direct human exploitation. We're flirting with disaster: 
new disease pandemics 
desertification 
major soil loss 
species extinction
empty aquifers 
massive (monoculture)crop loss

I'm familiar with the arguments in favor of the industrial ag system as it currently exists, but no matter how much you laud it, it's still risky AF, and increasingly so with climate breakdown. 

Urban ag (replacing space allocated to grass/vehicle asphalt) is critical resiliency

Growing even a tiny bit of the food we consume is healthy for us. 

Maybe we don't grow wheat/rice on our boulevards, but growing greens at home reduces the need for a delicate crop that comes via reefers (refrigerated semis) and in single use fossil fuel plastic.

More food forests + urban gardens isn't instead of densifying cities, but in addition to. Growing food isn't just about resiliency + stormwater management, but it's critical to human health (inc physical/mental) + community to get dirt under our nails, to breathe with plants

It's really odd and jarring to see that some urbanists are still pushing against urban food production as if the way we're growing/distributing food in industrial ag systems now is anything but catastrophic and extremely risky. 

We have to change EVERY system

Most of the stuff that happens in industrial animal ag:
Extreme exploitation of workers
New human diseases emerge from untried meat processing techniques
Frequent need for full herd culls + waste in/of that
Disease/toxins from processing cause serious disease in consumers

Monocultures/crops that increase risks of total crop loss/famine
Monocultures/crops that decrease/eliminate year-round ground cover & lead to major soil erosion
Theft of freshwater from others/future generations--from Colorado River, from the Ogallala Aquifer, from other sources

Soil, water, and air pollution
Pesticides/herbicides
Trademark-enforced crops forced on farmers
Eutrophication of lakes
Deadzones in deltas + NO3 release
Very problematic overuse of antibiotics
Novel-disease-creating conditions for livestock in many cases

Issues include:
systemic & massive exploitation of vulnerable workers
high CO2e emissions in production
storage/transport (including refrigeration) CO2e emissions
extremely high CO2e emissions from animal ag 
local toxicity/cancer clusters & environmental racism
waste emissions

Factory/industrial ag has a whole lot of potentially catastrophic issues and is a major contributor to spiraling climate breakdown, however. I am very tired of trying to suss out whether the agency staff I so enjoy (because I do!) are saying things that don't make sense because they're forced to in public by job constraints or because they're so steeped in it that they're not aware of the logical incoherence.

Because the people who live on high density residential/community corridors/bus routes are...
Not residents, I guess? 

Even though Mpls2040 very specifically, consciously, and deliberately chose to heavily concentrate allowed residential populations exactly along these streets

So they're also bus routes. But the busses are stuck behind private vehicles, who're being diverted by the traffic calming on side streets. We can't reduce lanes because transit isn't fast enough due to those cars and we also can't divert cars to "residential streets."

We can't do these measures on the dangerous streets because those are trucking routes. And car routes. 

They're trucking and car routes because we decided they'd be trucking and car routes in the Transportation Action Plan. We based that on...what they are now.

We are going to further our equity and vision zero goals by reducing traffic volumes/speeds on the slow streets where richer people live and diverting those vehicles to the streets where poorer people live and where people are regularly killed and injured.

I....

It...I...but...

This is part of what makes me believe car-culture is a high control group. While the plans are laid out with complete sincerity (by people I truly like and respect!), they're being undermined and contradicted at their base in the same sentence.

But the relentless double-speak that's required to foster a two-tiered, wealth/privilege based reality while repeating "equity and safety" is really and sincerely is damaging to my brain.

It's not good for any of us. This is training us to brainwash ourselves.

I don't doubt that there's no sense that we're anywhere near the political or professional will currently that can surmount the force that is entitled homeowners whose self-worth is wrapped up in being Residents Not Renters, especially given how Mpls divides renter power in NOs.

This is very much flirting with trickle down traffic engineering, in its best case scenario. 

We're basically using millions of dollars of city money to materially improve the living conditions of a handful of SFH residents in hopes that it'll eventually reduce driving overall.

But your scenario of individual side street traffic diverter choices is this (in my understanding):
You reduce your ADT/AQI on your side street by, say, 25%? 50%? 
You do nothing (very best case scenario) or increase ADT, worsen AQI, and slow transit on your community corridor.

Principles of induced demand suggest that some of the drivers diverted onto the bus route might find that just enough extra friction to not driver EXCEPT YOU'RE ALSO SLOWING TRANSIT so what does that friction do? Is it a wash?

When you use street diverters on side streets, you reduce the functionality of the grid for private vehicle drivers going distances for which a car starts making sense. You divert (FORCE) those drivers onto YOUR BUS ROUTE, slowing your transit, harming its ridership.

In your street grid design, your private vehicles have one single advantage to moving people: they can take alternate routes if things are backed up. And your transit has one single major limitation: it cannot ever shift to a different route without hurting its riders.

If you are designing a street grid, even if you ignore the heaping, steaming negative externalities of cars, you DO NOT WANT TO CO-LOCATE ON A SINGLE STREET THE FOLLOWING:
1. your private vehicle drivers
2. your fixed route public transit

In a decent timeline, these streets'd still be Special Types (given Mpls' culture of forcing uniformity on anything interesting), because they're uniquely zoned for/built with commercial+ high density residential & have transit. But logically, they'd be PLEASANT + NOT EXTRA TOXIC

The Street Type problem is that our densest residential corridors (by happenstance, then zoning) are also commercial and therefore transit routes. Somehow in the fuckery that's been decades of car-1st-planning, those're ALSO where drivers are funneled, despite all basic logic

There's never a clear answer. As far as I've learned in my   ongoing questioning, it's this:
1. we're constrained by old notions of Street Types that got COMPLETELY EFFED by adding cars and not thinking about the consequences, and 
2. Actual equity isn't politically tenable here.

I mean, I've tried repeatedly to challenge it, but with little success. Bringing it up seems to cause confusion and discomfort for the engineers/planners who're occasionally forced to deal with problem people like me (not warned about that enough in grad school, I guess?).

Why does Minneapolis have two tiers of acceptability in ADT, AQI, access to green space, and safety from noxious cars? 

Why are these applied in ways that are so dramatically different? 

Why has it gone unchallenged/unexplained in Mpls2040, the TAP, and 20 year Streets Funding?

In early pandemic, people in SFH w yards blocked side streets with private barriers to create unsanctioned (but unchallenged) outside gathering areas. 

Meanwhile, dragracing/stunt driving/speeding/tire burning increased along high density residential streets of mostly renters.

Wouldn't you want traffic calming along streets that are:
where people cross the street for (sometimes in a hurry), wait for, and take transit
where lots of people also work, shop, eat out, do errands, meet with friends, grab coffee

Imagine you're told to deploy traffic calming measures to maximize equity/efficacy. Wouldn't you aim them at streets that are:
high injury/crash
high density residential
disproportionately low-income/vulnerable
adjacent to schools/senior housing
community gathering destinations

Make two columns, one for Side St and the other for Arterial Ave (I'm v clever tonight!). Then ask yourself:
How many people live/work/go to school along them and what is their wealth/vulnerability?
What is the air quality currently? 
What is the speed limit?
What is the ADT?

May I suggest, Fellow Transpo Advocates, that when you hear "traffic calming" proposed or reflect on where it's already installed, you pay attention to where it's being suggested? Then compare the context of those streets to what's happening on nearby bus routes/arterials.

Instead, they're installed on low-density side streets, protecting mostly property owners whose homes are set back from the street. And by disrupting the grid for drivers, they exacerbate health inequities, funneling cars to where more--and poorer--people actually live/work.

For anyone interested in my roasted chickpea recipe. It's also my dehydrated-for-camping-chickpea recipe. 

I love chickpeas so much! And they're so good for most of us, nice fiber and slow release energy and gentle on the planet and all that! https://t.co/yXDMcmaWdA

@playinprogress * I haven't played around with how different temps or spices impact de/rehydration, nor have I looked into other people's recipes or storage times for this. Mostly speculation + used it a few times for camping and for sudden chickpea curry cravings.

@playinprogress Haven't had them rehydrate to 100% fresh state, but they get 95% of the way there*. I suspect (idk) they have a fairly long shelf-life when dehydrated (months?), so a useful option (inc unseasoned) for those with disabilities who can bulk prep food, if freezer storage is limited.

@playinprogress Yes, that is the magic info trial + error + other humans helped me learn! I skew towards lower temps when starting things, and they were SO TASTY but also felt like I was going to break my teeth but I couldn't stop eating them!

@playinprogress When I cook a full batch (~4 cups dried), they last me 3-4 days. But if you are a reasonable person who doesn't wake up and fall asleep with chickpeas in your bed, you can store them pre-cooked/dehydrated to use as "instant" chickpeas both for home and camping cooking.

@playinprogress Lower temps make them harder instead of crunchy. Higher temps and you're flirting with still soft inside. 

As long as you don't burn them (and they burn individually, so pick out burnt ones), they're still usable. You can rehydrate them by boiling them, then sautee w veggies

@playinprogress 3. season (oil, salt, garlic powder, smoked paprika, berbere, msg if you've got it) to taste (remember they shrink to 1/2 size, so make half as salty as desired)
4. spread on baking sheet, single layer. Roast at 250-350F. Stir/rotate/switch pans at 15 minute intervals

@playinprogress 1. soak in water for ~8 hours (they start clicking as they swell at about hour 4, it's v cute but wakes me up if soaking overnight!), drain 
2. add water, boil for 1+ hour, til the texture is tasty in your teeth, drain (can save liquid (aquafaba) for egg white replacement stuff)

Not every neurodiverse or disabled person has the same barriers.

I get SOME KIND OF WAY (impassable barrier) when how I eat is the opposite of multi-solving, when I understand that I'm nourishing myself (non-emergency/special occasion) thru unnecessary harm to others/self.

To clarify on toxins, I'm talking specifically about:
BPA/BPS/related chemical compounds found in the lining of canned food
PFAS in moldable compostable containers
Plastics generally

Our regulatory system does not protect us from v toxic (and needless) single use packaging.

I get that for some disabled/neurodiverse people, pre-packaged is 100% the way to go because fed is best!

But for me, if I'm at all hangry/stressed, I often find plastic waste + known toxins in packaging a very active source of distress/rumination + barrier to feeding myself.

I add the ferments to:
rice or pasta with some combo of:
beans/chickpeas
veggies [onions, fresh greens, (frozen) veggies, (dried) mushrooms]
an egg
toasted sesame seeds
roasted sunflower seeds

I add the granola on top of:
steel cut oats + amaranth cooked with dried fruits/spices

@neonbabel It has a definite decision-making hump/slight learning curve (mostly inertia for me), but neither is hard, both are v flexible (can stop in the middle for a day), and the change is HUGE. I can do short-duration quarterly projects where thrice daily breaks me.

My fermented vegetable mix includes 6+ food species and my granola is 11 nuts/seeds/grains + 7 spices (plus oil/sugar), so even if I just ate those, I'm getting a variety of (micro)nutrients, fiber, carbs, fats, and some protein. 

Both are way cheaper than buying prepackaged.

As someone with ADHD/autism who is surprised every day by the need to eat again, I've very drastically decreased the time/effort I need by making:
1. fermented veggies (2-3hrs/3 months) to eat daily (ferments also v good for brain health)

What are the ways we hold institutions to account while also supporting our allies who remain in them as progressive voices of dissent, as whistleblowers, as stopgaps in worst case scenarios, as strategists, as witnesses + recorders, as daylighters?

We have a history of boycotts/"cancel culture"/mass resignations/strikes and other ways to deny our complicity to individuals or corporations or organizations that're actively doing harm. But this isn't a tool we can apply equally to every institution/in every setting.

This could mean the people waking up to the cultic thinking embedded in many of our worst systems, but it also might mean that for those stuck in such systems professionally/etc, accepting (or recruiting others for) positions of greater power/responsibility even as a stopgap.

To change destructive systems as rapidly as we must, we need to have people within them who're resisting their machinations, who can see the points where change is possible and are able + willing to push against relentless intertwined forces of bureaucracy + social norms

How do we as a community work to ensure that leadership roles of power/responsibility are held by those up to it? How does our mutual aid encompass people with a variety of needs, including people who have privilege and who step into lightning-rod positions of discomfort?
@NilaJones3 That's super interesting! Any thoughts on how that came to be or how it functioned for those involved/for the community at large?

How do we meet our needs--inc self-care--without shirking our responsibility to step forward? Without leaving power vacuums that're open for those who're driven not by an ethos of collective good and community care, but by their ego or narcissism or cultic thinking or sadism?

We're at a fundamentally discomfiting inflection point in the world, and everything we're doing in these moments, these months, the next few years is part of determining the possibility of any future "work-life balance" not just for ourselves but for those who come after us.

Inversely, I have qualms about privileged progressives who decline power/responsibility due to concerns about "work/life balance" or other myopic reasons that're fundamentally about short term individual comfort. 

What're the broader consequences of this abdication of potential?

For example, running for office requires not just a level of perceptive-self-confidence/vision-of-self that is tied in to a white supremacist culture, but comes with additional costs for those who aren't white cis men, and that's on top of other barriers to entry/success when in.

I respect the people I've seen who're ready/willing to step into leadership roles but who put in time and effort to look for who isn't there (not just when these opportunities arise). I wish we talked about how to nurture people in these roles who haven't been groomed for them

I've heard a fair number of reasons given when the privileged people being encouraged to take leadership/power/responsibility roles hesitate or decline them. The one that resonates most in my ethos is a goal to elevate marginalized/unrepresented people to hold those roles

What does it look like to see leadership roles with power/responsibility being collectively held? We know that many of these functionally have been such (whether electeds who work seamlessly with their aides or roles where a spouse/partner has been a defacto 100% partner)

This one's a sticky widget, because:
1. working in settings with many narcissists/sadists is soul-crushing
2. burn-out is real (hence self-care)
3. effectively wielding power within corrupt systems is thankless + difficult
4. one ends up a lightning rod for supporters & haters

Not seeking out or rejecting opportunities to hold more responsibility/power doesn't eliminate those roles or (on its own) weaken the power they hold. It is a measure that protects us individually only, not collectively. Sometimes it's a way to protect our ego or our reputation.

I'm making up number (dangerous), but my point is solely that our individual choices (in positions of privilege) to decline positions and roles of power are themselves something we need to interrogate, but as individuals and in community.

Say 95% of emotionally stable/ethically minded people would turn down a promotion to a certain level of power due to its personal costs. Say 95% of narcissistic and/or sadistic people would seek out more power. 

Even without power having corrosive effects, we'd be in a bad way.

There's the old adage (from Catch-22? always heard it from my cousin) about each person rising to the level of their own incompetence, but that doesn't account for malice or sadism or even a motivation to implement cult-goals (whether apocalyptic Christianity or KKK or ???)

I don't think this is--in any way--the way the world should be, but it's our current power-structure. Those of us who are ethical, collectively-oriented people have to not only practice self-care, but also know when "self-sacrifice" is critical to creating that better world.

Imo, the opportunity to hold power/responsibility is a function of structural privilege of all sorts, so discussions of the personal costs of an individual choice to seek/reject that opportunity should include an understanding of that privilege and the responsibility it brings.

I don't think all people who seek positions of leadership/power/responsibility are malignant, but a subset of particularly malicious and/or destructive people do seek out power, and the consequences of this are untenable.

Specifically about leadership roles that come with responsibility/power. The risks we face if collective-oriented, ethical people who don't want power/responsibility decline it when offered it because of the costs associated with it. The pool that leaves of people for those roles
I've been thinking a fair amount in the last week about the dangers of cultural messages of individualistic self-care that don't include nuance for when and how we negotiate self-sacrifice.

Despite some recent tweets, I'm not usually a huge crier. I cry over:
missing my dead(ish) people
humans coming together for one another in v specific collective self-sacrificing ways
frustration/rage/pain over injustice
grief re climate
the beauty of lake ice

The second photo, however, was what feels like the most representative of my beautiful lake ice, with bubbles and cracks and fissures and a little bit of sinuous leafy lake plant trapped in there. Closer to this one. I actually started crying as the image was revealed https://t.co/qBjhBielra

The first photo we printed was one of the radial city portals, like this one. I love these and have been slowly noticing patterns in what might cause them to appear where they do. Our darkroom guide suggested it as a stellar candidate for the process. https://t.co/RGiKvtrAYn

We were mostly there for my flame to learn (I was there because I'm a sucker for road trips and Chicago's positivity rate is 1.25% so please & thanks some humans) but I got to play around printing some negatives of my ice photos and then developing/processing them and OMG!!!

Got to spend last weekend in my flame's friend's basement darkroom in Chicago. My flame's an exceptional photographer and his friend is as well (plus obsessive about printing processes). I haven't printed in a darkroom since I took Intro to Photography at the U as a highschooler.

I'm so so beyond excited, friends! I've got Serious Plans to actually print (like me! with the help of supply chains and also friends who know a lot more than me!) my lake ice photos on paper, using processes that feel right and good.

This apparently is the weather profile I need. That early Jan melt was v depressing, but turned into GLORY by Jan 10th. https://t.co/mQcs3vkw20

Damn it, made the mistake of watching one of my videos trying to capture the (methane?) magenta bubble explosions in the ice, and the background sound is the horridness of Lake Street but also the sharp twangs of ice cracking even during the day and I'm sobbing missing it.

And there I was, alone on the lake. Alone! The full weight of trying to capture and share this beauty with others all on me and my little phone camera. 

It's enough to have me crying now, looking through photos, that we're eleven months out from this beauty possibly returning

January 24th was life altering beauty, the kind that makes your whole being ache with what the world can contain. Temps were "feels like" -20F, relentless winds coming across Bde Maka Ska sculpting mounds of snow on teal/black ice. It was almost impossible not to cry from beauty

I shared a little of it on here, but I was out there for hours a day. Dec 18/Jan 19 account for a few thousand absolutely glorious ice photos, the kind that make me want to wear them on sandwich boards and walk up and down Hennepin so all you all could join me out there in awe

@kathysaxzim Yeeeees. That is its thing. It's a helpful alarm system, but once you've determined the source of the smoke in the room and are acting, there's nothing to be gained by the shrill incessant noise and it def doesn't help with the action-taking.
It's at the ready, for the moment I do feel anxious, to hand me what it thinks I need: that justification, full of citations, graphs, a robust bibliography.

But the anxiety-brain is at the ready--I realize that sometimes when I talk to someone. I'm sitting here listening to cult podcasts while working or mending and its apparently in some windowless back-brain chaining together potential but very specific paths to any level of doom.

I'm not a huge fan of this whole pandemic thing, but it's curious to experience the emotional states of the physical isolation thing. Mostly, I haven't felt anxious so much as unsteady/uncalibrated. Like balancing on one foot with your eyes closed.

Which is why I say treatment-resistant. The "treatment" of arguing with the person who is anxious ceases to work as effectively, as our anxiety learns how to sway us, because what we're addressing is a/the topic, not the feeling.

If you deal with the discomfort of anxiety by seeking to disprove its source, you end up with a fairly skilled subconscious that also has access to all the knowledge you have and definitely is out to win in front of the jury of your whole brain.
Or if our response to someone (inc ourselves) expressing anxiety is "about what?" we're forcing an explanation of causal relationship where one might not exist.

What I mean is this: if we feel anxious "because of [reason]" & then focus on disproving or undermining or controlling [reason] without attending to the emotional state, then we just get better at justifying the state, rather than processing/sitting with the emotional distress.
Current theory-of-being-human: insisting on treating reasons for anxiety instead of feelings of anxiety creates treatment-resistant anxiety.

I'm lucky that I had parents (and siblings) open to theoretical and abstract conversation. I'm lucky that I was an early and voracious reader with library access. I'm lucky I was raised with a religious tradition that was not death-denying and that encouraged thought/questioning.

Like when you start studying algebra and you're like "but this is kindergarten all over again, except you're writing "x" instead of a little box?!?" It's the same concept, but framed differently and age-appropriately. 

Some concepts we approach over and over for new learning

I wish (or think I wish) I'd had access to Foucault in particular in elementary school (I recognized in his words on prisons the arbitrary non-consensual authoritarianism and panopticon of the US school system).

Isn't this all really just the human condition, from the emergence of our metacognition, awareness of Truth + Death?

Don't people say children the first/original philosophers? 

Why are we making kids turn ten all alone in existential angst?!

But also I can't quite believe that? 

I was introduced to the terms epistemology + ontology in my senior year of college and my whole thought was that that was language/framework what I craved so desperately starting around in kindergarten

I'm realizing in the last year and a half that maybe my childhood was a little atypical not just in the material ways I was aware of, but in the sheer amount of time I spent deeply obsessed with philosophy (inc theology and ethics) as a means of knowing how to human

Fwiw, I did (years and years later) eventually talk to my family about my midlife crisis of turning ten and my mother and one sibling had both also experienced the same silent but crushingly awareness of mortality at the event of their tenth birthdays. 

Yay genetics?

Just you, alone in your mortality. Your approaching death in your face as you ready yourself for sleep each night by slipping on the giant t-shirt that reminds you that "life can't be rewound" while memorizing the words of a dead man, and you mouth "Out, out, brief candle!"

To be clear, turning ten is basically moving from childhood to your Death Years. Single digits to the double digits you'll statistically die in. 

Can't talk to parents about it because they've got it so much worse. Can't talk to little siblings because they're joyfully innocent.

In 4th/5th grade, we had tshirts for some sort of school media thing that said "Panasonic: because life can't be rewound."

And we performed MacBeth. I learned the "tomorrow and tomorrow and tomorrow/creeps in this petty pace from day to day" soliloquy. 

I also turned ten.

I wish I had more distinct memories of what I took in that informed this (what I was reading, who I was talking to, what was formative), but mostly I know that a lot of it was unspeakable for me, because I found it really distressing and felt that it was far worse for adults.

Idk, I was fairly obsessed with philosophical topics as a kid (thanks, death!). What is life, what is suffering, what is truth, what is god, what do we know, how do we know it, what are we to one another, what is time, what is being, what is will, what are words, why is anything

That's not always his response, of course. He's fairly adept (imo) at parsing the differences between who's a kid learning who they are in community, who's an attention seeker who'll be emboldened by response, and who's needing active deescalation. 

That's the space of calm.

His response was "she was wanting a response so I gave her the one she wanted."

He wasn't startled, alarmed, or scared, (all of which he could have had reason to be) but intuited that her state was as a teen kind of "proving" she existed within the world, so he played along.

Listening to this, my father's embodied stoicism in a lot of ways. I think of when we were walking downtown and a teen in a group got in his face v briefly and shouted "boo" and he responded "ahhh, oh no!"

I was really confused at his response, and asked what was going on.

The idea of a negative interaction being all about the person being insulted (in the example) is also not resonating, maybe because of the privilege it reflects. An emotional even keel doesn't mean no response--it's understanding + responding to community from a place of ~calm.

If we're seeking meaning entirely within ourselves--even in this stoic way--how would we possibly find it? We're wired for togetherness, to halve our grief and double our joy and as the reason for our righteous burning anger. 

And that itself tempers our self-destructive states.

What's missing so far in this explanation of stoicism (not done with the episode) is the relational aspect of our lives and the ways in which as humans our meaning is never our alone. Our place in community, our connection to those who have gone before and will come after us.

And--the piece I learned not in childhood--grief just is, like breathing, like hunger. Other emotional states are malleable, productive (except when they aren't, hence emotional regulation), instructive. But grief is its own fullness

What-ifs or might-have-beens are the alluring but toxic side paths from the road of "learn from the past" + "after action report everything."

We cannot know that other world, and it of course seems less painful. But we can learn from what has happened in this one to help others.

Otherwise, after assessing for my own actions/role, it's somewhere between:
I cannot control this and it is what it is
We're on an adventure now!
What can I learn or what am I learning?
Oh, of course we've got a comedy of errors! (rarely)

Acceptance. Curiosity. Irony.

But that agitation at plans disrupted (transit, whatever) isn't a source of anger or other negative emotions for me generally, unless it triggers a sense of patterns of injustice and a community protectiveness.

I feel a little judgy about what they describe. Flight is such a morass of intersecting privilege that it's hard for me to understand why they'd be prone to frustration/anger except from a place for entitlement (if so, go back to exercises to reduce that self-centeredness).

Fwiw, I don't think I really know or understand the emotion they're seeking to avoid--I extremely rarely experience that kind of anger, for a few reasons (if we assume that my childhood brain hacks for stoicism are causal rather than solely biological personality)

Then, the guest speaks of the a game to avoid anger at being inconvenienced at the airport by a delayed flight, by (as a mental exercise) imagining that they are being tested by stoic gods who seek to strengthen them. IMO, this is a surface level start to reframing experiences.

Most people have different goals for themselves and different perceptions of the source of joy across their lifespan. Just a developmental thing, I think? To live to avoid regret is to project something we cannot known onto someone we may never have the chance to become.

I worked as an election judge on 9/11 when we had some voters coming in saying "history is happening right now; this is where I will have wanted to be" and it enraged me. They made other people's deaths about them; bearing witness is about being fully present, not as Self.

As a kid, I did a lot of listening and learning at funerals where there's often self-reflection from adults about their regrets or what they've done to avoid regrets. But both assume the point of view of a future self who is knowable in a world that's predictable, outside now.

For example, the pre-nostalgia perhaps can be effective for achieving a scarcity-pleasure, but it's not necessary often, and it can create its own beast of living outside the moment--the people who are never satisfied in the relationship they're in, for example.

Actually, I'm finding the suggested exercises so far fairly crude (not in the sense of bad, but just unrefined and with significant room for a clearer and healthier implementation). Too transactional or self-based for being very sustainable and somewhat counter-productive

I strongly disagree with leveraging our mortality as the barometer to calibrate our experiences and find joy in their scarcity and I have some moral problems with it, but I do very actively practice joy-finding pleasure to easily reach the same point as they're discussing.

Listening to the latest @HiddenBrain episode (repeat) on stoicism. Turns out I've been a typical stoic since early elementary school inasmuch as I've been painfully aware of the fleeting nature of life, pre-nostalgic/grieving and also hacking my brain to reduce negative emotion.

My rudderless food is delicious, though! Canned tomatoes + lentils + coconut cream + onion, mixed frozen veggies, curry leaves, ginger, turmeric, garlic, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, nutmeg, black pepper, fenugreek, cayenne. Topped with toasted sesame seeds.

Also also I don’t always consult a recipe before cooking and/or have a range of ingredients (eg tonight), so sometimes it’s critical to have enough options to be able to find a half dozen that are specific to what I’ve already done or have on hand.

Also, I do not use recipes as step-by-step guides. I like to look at a bunch of recipes and notice the patterns, then decide accordingly. So I need a minimum 1/3-1/2 dozen recipes for each thing I’m making.

Here’s the thing. Sometimes I want to confirm that I’m on the right path with my cooking (eg lentil tomato curry tonight) but I don’t want to give clicks to people who’re appropriating and profiting off other people’s work and cuisines.

E.g. 12 weeks post-covid infection and 12 weeks post-non-infection are both 12 weeks living in the uncertainty and stress of this pandemic. 

It's critical to try to tease out what's the result of infection vs the result of the shared context in which infection happens.

And this is after having a baseline that was altered by years of full-time caretaking (which exacerbated executive dysfunction in my adhd/autism). Covid isn't the only part of the pandemic impacting our physiology, obviously.

I know from reading people's self-descriptions that what I've experienced is not in the same range as the impacts of Long Covid. But in a survey, I'd check off boxes for an increase in:
headaches
weak limbs (?)
fatigue
insomnia
muscle pain
loss of concentration

What I appreciate about this study is the inclusion of uninfected (per self-report) individuals. For me, over the course of the pandemic so far, I've experienced an increase in impacts that are nominally (listed here) as symptoms of Long Covid.

But I haven't felt it in quite the same way or to the same extent with other groups, and I've wondered over and over why that is. How much of it is the culture of the group, and how much is its structure? Do others experience it like this in this committee and if not why not?

There's a whole lot of care and community I feel with a lot of the people I've volunteered on other boards with, people I really like and respect and who've shared with and cared about me in similar material/emotional ways.

In Dec, we met up at the grocery store, and he helped me carry groceries home (!!!) before we walked a half dozen miles. This month, knowing I haven't been to the grocery store since then, he shared with me a friend's homegrown dried fish pepper for making beans, now on the stove

After these gatherings, I'd gotten in the habit of walking with my co-chair, @petervader, often brainstorming around our own subcommittee and ideas for it (e.g. trailmix). We've continued to walk together when possible, though not nearly as regularly.

It was a time when newer members clarified jargon, where we wondered about projects we'd seen ages ago, where we ranted about walking in Mpls. But moreover, it was where we learned more about one another and just shared and cared for and about each other

Pre-pandemic, we'd almost always have at least a handful of people interested in grabbing a bite to eat or a drink or walking to see a specific area of interest after each meeting, inviting meeting presenters and member's loved ones to join us.

One of the things we'd started doing pre-pandemic, in the subcommittee I've co-chaired for a while, was bringing (often homemade) trail mix/granola to share amongst ourselves and with our guests, asking for volunteers, but never requiring it. Food is the free parking of walking

The one exception is, coincidentally, the committee where we've built and encouraged the most robust community, where we've shared the most meals and walks and connections across our personal imperfect selves/lives.

At the end of 2021, I stepped off most of the boards/committees I was on, not because I don't wholeheartedly and enthusiastically support them, but because I felt I'd accomplished as much as I felt I could within them, and I need to reorient my efforts again

@silverindow @snyde043 Multi-Level Marketing aka pyramid or Ponzi scheme

Not sure of the necessity or utility of all that but I suspect that the framework is [structured, second-nature, constant, complex] enough to stave off a fairly wide range of high-control thinking. Maybe. Certainly doesn’t win me friends

How would I know if the choices or decisions I deemed moral or good were not skewed by the bias of my own desires? Or other biases? How would I avoid complacency? Integrate new data? Create a framework that did not implicitly believe my humanity or life above anyone else’s?

So you have to develop a framework to make your choices and guide your behavior. How do we measure what is good or bad? How much does intention matter? How do we weigh harm? 

But also, where are the biases within this framework and its application by this fraught human self?

You know, when you’re a kid & you believe you can grow up to be anything? And also that it seems illogical that “anything” includes singer but not serial killer? You assume no one wants to become a serial killer so hubris in thinking that isn’t you is itself where the risk starts

I’ve also been realizing in listening to these that my childhood “hobby” of metacognition was both weird af and protective. My understanding was that I was unbridled but indeterminate potential, whether for good or to do harm. I worked to set up safeguards against turning bad
That’s prob the cult I’m highly susceptible to too. The cult of the underdog. I have to check that tendency in myself, make sure I’m not letting it skew my perception.

So the next time that friend visited a few years later, my brother prepped my father with some story about how his friend as an unsavory character but maybe trying to do better. And my father was v open and friendly (as my bro knew he would be).

So fairly prophylactic for lovebombing or anything presented as truth or anyone claiming to know the truth.

Actually, reminds me of when my father met a friend of my brother’s and just found him smug in a smarmy way, was fairly cold to him.

Thinking about in what contexts I’d be or have been vulnerable is interesting. I was raised to be wary of anyone selling or giving anything. The better the offer, the greater the suspicion. Also saying nice things about the person they’re speaking to. Also speaking with certainty
@MaryMorseMarti I wish I didn’t. Harshing my vibe today especially.

@SimpleBoatMan Listening to episodes of Life After MLM the last 48 hours. 

Definitely currently appreciating individuals sharing/reflecting on their experiences over purely theoretical—I was more into theory stuff a few years ago in tandem with reading about Scientology and Mormonism

@SimpleBoatMan Trust Me is my fav of the explicitly cult ones. Have listened to a lot of whatever pops up when I type in “cult” (inc the whole oeuvre of some) but only subscribe to that one. Also Something Was Wrong, which is more individual-level controlling people/abusive relationships.

I’m realizing why I avoid these conversations generally. I have no interest in people’s beliefs (except for where they intersect with behaviors and decision-making and also the layer that is culture). And language in this case is a barrier. Basically invisible false cognates.

Listening to podcasts where people are diving into their own history + frameworks for understanding/seeking meaning in the world, those who actively reject religion share their new understanding using language that’s basically identical to how I learnt to conceptualize god.

It’s rare that I hear someone raised Protestant or non-religious talk about their religious upbringing and have any sense of shared experience/framework. Very hit and miss with others raised Catholic or those raised Muslim. Very frequent with those raised Jewish. Idk.

Also part of listening to cult/MLM podcasts is realizing how disparate (to the point of virtually no vent diagram overlap except perhaps god as a homonym) experiences are within what gets labeled “religion.”

And they dive a bit into some of what can prime people for this kind of exploitation, including childhood indoctrination into dogmatic/authoritarian thinking, curiosity/openness (for cults), and trauma or major life changes.

One of the things I really appreciate about the cult/MLM podcasts I’ve heard is that most of them are really clear about how this isn’t the fault of the people who’ve been fooled. That the groups are exploiting some of our best human traits &/or some cognitive biases to do harm

I have virtually no notable direct experience with cults/MLMs beyond car culture (and other related cultish structures of the US status quo), so that’s also on my mind. (Assuming I’d be aware of it, who knows)

Car culture is less like an MLM than a straight up cult, but the anti-MLM activist scene as described makes me think of my lovely folks (inc you all on here) doing the hard work to make deprogramming an option for folks and to protect those outside that “in” group

Expanding my interest in high control groups/cults to listening to anti-MLM podcasts and playing a little game where I see if I have to change any major words to make the critiques apply 100% to car culture or the work of climate/equity transportation activists

4. Reduce entrance/exit occurrences as much as possible. 
5. Close off any other spaces when you leave + until you've filtered/exchanged air in the space where your door is. I nailed a wool blanket into the moulding over a doorway to do this. Reduces volume of air to be filtered.

1. Seal interior doors to prevent omicron-bearing drafts (inc at base)--be cautious while applying
2. Keep N95 mask on after re-entering home. Open windows for air exchange (no idea how long, but the temp differential + a fan might help)

@TricksyRaccoon Fermented vegetables! Grate (organic?) vegetables (I use: carrots, cabbage, jicama, radish, watermelon rind, cucumber, onion, etc) + spices (garlic, ginger for me). Add salt (to taste: pickle-level). Stir it all. Put in jar, add vinegar if water/brine doesn't cover it.

@TricksyRaccoon Roasted chickpeas are amazing! Soak/cook/drain, then season with salt/oil/msg/garlic powder/smoked paprika/berbere/your fav spices, then bake in a single layer at about 250-300F, stirring/shaking occasionally until done.

I made vinegar out of tiny apples growing adjacent to a highway in Duluth. I didn't want to eat more than 1-2, because highway, but I made vinegar with them, and that's been my hair conditioner when I shower (it deepens over time, and smells SO SO GOOD a year later!)

For example, you can make vinegar out of a lot of different fruits. The whole fermenting process is about long-term preservation of food so it's prophylactic against foodborne illness, at least as I understand it. But vinegar has substantial non-consumable uses too!

My point is mostly that a LOT of foods have secondary uses beyond eating/drinking them, so even if you're not willing to eat dumpstered food, there's bunches of stuff you/we could be doing with it that's better than incinerating it or even composting it.

We’ll see. The pandemic uncertainty is hard, but not super hard. This vague plan is more certainty and control than I have felt for years at a time. (Also v lucky in so many ways to be able to have these particular choices.)

My expectations (ha!) are that even a few more cases of omicron locally or spread starting nationally will trigger me to lock down harder + urge others to reduce transmission activities too + rapid test more (if we can). The initial predicted duration is “til we know more”

I do have strong ethical concerns and frustrations but that’s separate from the curiosity-chasing. 

My take since I first read about the new variant has been: 
Precautionary principle
Accept uncertainty as we learn more
Raise concerns as appropriate
Protect others

I’m also sharing info via various text threads and occasionally in twitter threads w strangers.

I’m not feeling anxious or distressed about it at all—this variant really just triggered the special interest thing and I’m really enjoying the learning/process.
Additionally, I am eating my fermented veggies every day as well as taking melatonin. Was already doing both, but both have possible correlations w being prophylactics for covid.

I’m also trying to encourage safe (N95) masking, and I’ve sent a few emails and made phone calls to ask about ventilation standards at places. Small agitations where I can to share concern, solutions.

With omicron on the horizon, we’re hanging out more indoors/in person, planning to lock down harder when it hits until we know more about it. 

If no omicron, would likely hold off for more household vaccine protection + local transmission lower than 10%

@elorraine_ @mplsalex I think so many fewer people would complain if the city did basic educational comms, inc the weird stuff that causes delays! I want daily/weekly vernacular convo project updates stapled to posts along street projects.

When it happens in multiple conversations in different spheres near-simultaneously, it fills me with a lot of self-doubt and angst. 

Where's the drop-out/disconnect/miss-connect happening? How can I figure that out? How can I solve for it? What's my contribution to it occurring?

Am I not stating X clearly? Is my statement of X based on presumptions I haven't shared? Is there something included in my X that is implicit and I'm not aware of? Why isn't Y making sense to me? Is there presumed shared knowledge I'm ignoring?

It makes me feel like I'm possible going mad or have gone mad. It's not about disagreement at all--that happens w clear communication. It's about thinking my words mean X, but then a response that seems to be to Y or Z, and this over and over.

I don't think of myself as a particularly poor or indirect communicator (just verbose) but it's really hard on me when I'm having major failures in one-on-one communication--I really have trouble parsing what's going wrong and therefore how to solve it.

In a super-infectious airborne disease with a variant with immune escape + exponential increase, that means we each need to understand ourselves as the potential source of smog, and mask up in N95s. Bare minimum.
Luckily that's also more efficient. For public health, you put the filter for smog on the point-source for pollution, not on the intake mechanics of every life form potentially harmed by it.

To respect the autonomy of others, you don't demand they protect themselves from you. You manage yourself as a potential source of harm. 

Do you see the difference? 

The onus is on the potential source of harm, not the potential victim/recipient.

This isn't about paralysis or living in a bubble, but about fundamental basic respect for the lives and bodies and choices of others. 

To decide we "know best" for others is paternalistic at best, generally unfounded and out of step with a fluid pandemic context.

Consent is critical. Consent includes context. Consent is a conversation, and consent can be revoked. 

When you refuse to wear an N95 in communal indoor settings, you are denying others their bodily autonomy, their right to manage their own health/risks.

Years ago, I was in a relationship where the other person hid from me that they were seeing someone else as well. By far, the most upsetting part of this was that they denied me accurate knowledge I needed to make my own choices about my body + the risks I was willing to take.
And as we learn more about airborne infectious diseases and masks (thanks, science!), we know that "masking up" means wearing an N95.

The health risks we each take should be, as much as possible, our free choices, and consensual when they're about the risk of infectious diseases where humans are the primary vector. 

Masking up in indoor public settings is about respecting other people's bodily autonomy.

We wash our hands to protect ourselves and others from unnecessary disease spread. 

We use condoms to protect ourselves and others from unnecessary disease spread. 

We wear masks to protect ourselves and others from unnecessary disease spread. 

Not super complicated.

Part of our work in shifting to sustainable/original transportation is relearning how to dress for our mode and our bodies. Cold feet are THE WORST, and I'm sharing this because I don't see others sharing much of what works well for them walking miles in climates like Mpls'

Anyhow, I know kids boots and boot liners aren't as sexy as ebikes, but deciding what boots and liners to order is literally my major transportation purchase of the last few years, and I'm expecting for the new few too, given my experiences with their quality.

I exchanged messages about liners and boots with one of their customer service people last winter. They were v v knowledgeable, curious, and patient despite me being me (long detailed messages as you'd expect from me).

The main reason I'm getting new ones instead of attempting repair is that they're finally springing leaks in the bottom balls of the feet, but other points are close to worn through too. Will try to harvest sides for sandal soles, though.

In terms of wear, they seem to have significantly outlasted my general 500 miles/pair of shoes or boots, whether due to walking differently in winter or to quality. 

The liner went first, at the heel, which I repaired a few times but the new liners look reinforced at that point!

What I hadn't experienced prior to the Snobusters was tall fully waterproof winter boots. They're GREAT for walking at the edges of the lakes on the thin ice or even in the shallow water. It makes for a special kind of winter fun to break through + freedom to explore/adventure

They've got some decent looking "adult" options as well if you want, slightly pricier and for warmer temps. "Men's" sizes start way larger than my feet, and "women's" sizes default to narrow which I find restrictive coming from years of minimal/zero-drop shoes.
@avocadoplex Yes, it seems to be a limiting factor!!! And sometimes lake ice safety means not doing fast little warmth jigs on slick ice with no one within 200'...

I'm also thinking of trying the Glacial 4 ($72), which I'm a little hesitant about after always blistering at 1-2mi in a secondhand pair of Sorel's in a kinda similar-looking style, but they're supposed to be good to -58F, and I want more time w lake ice
https://t.co/mDpgTtGXhe

This time, I'm planning to get the Icebreaker ($55) + an extra liner, which is good to -40F. Different style liner, and I'm excited! I really push my feet and my cold tolerance when I'm out on the ice standing/laying still to take ice photos.
https://t.co/1FJxS2fhlo

I've been wearing my two pair of snobuster boots for yeeears, they're on sale for $36 (my first pair was $22 on clearance at the Rack). Good to -28F. I'd recommend an extra liner, if you're a walker (not on sale, but nice to have one drying). 
https://t.co/kZdfpUL1Ia

My flame now is a straight man, perhaps the first straight man I've dated. Except if he's queer (eg dating me)? But I read as v cis-woman (in body)? What is queerness in the partner of an enby? We haven't talked about that, in part due to my fear of [rejection] from past partners

@elorraine_ There was a british book I read once where the older kids in a school got to have the younger kids run out to the outhouses and sit on the toilet seats to warm them up for them and that is what we're missing in being anti-royalists, I guess

So in his view, as far as I understood it, a bi man dating an enby (who reads as a cis woman) long enough turned both non-queer? Prob should alert Michelle Bachman's people to this!

(I was not at all ok with erasing me, and it was part of the dissolution of that relationship)

I read as a woman to most people. I've dated rarely, but in that, a few bi men, including one who couldn't really handle me being enby, who wanted me to hide that, who felt dating me long enough made him no longer bi (idk, not me), and that my nonbinaryness was...kind of a choice

I didn't act on that knowledge, because if there's one thing that being an outsider makes clear, it's that you don't always want the insiders in your outsider spaces. So I tried to stay out, protect those spaces for those for whom they were intended, those needing them most.

I've paused Sex Ed, in the arc of whether dating someone who's nonbinary makes the other person queer. I knew I was queer in highschool, a decade away from learning that being not-a-woman legitimized me as queer, just knew then that queer included me and felt like home somehow

Idk. My mother misgenders me occasionally, and it's always if we're fighting. I've been correcting her since the first time she called me a woman when I was 12, and it still feels like a slap, like the pain of someone I love looking right through me, past me, denial of existence.

And cis friends who read as androgynous have shared this complaint too. 

I also misgender people, and I hate it. A lifetime of being enby, of having that heightened attention, hasn't inoculated me from this broken system. I'm still working/learning/trying/correcting.

I feel odd and unseen when I see enbys depicted as default reading as androgynous by current standards, as if there is still some truth to a forced gender binary, where our bodies can be sexed by any pos as if they're a map to who we actually are.

Idk. I am grateful for all the enbys who are out there living themselves in every way, but to be understood by others as anything but the cissest of cis binary people is something I wanted badly and also knew wasn't compatible with my body/budget/energy.

But I was also learning at the same time (entering the world more and more on my own, without family in every intro) that I read as white to many people, and that that was an equally futile and frankly uninteresting fight to be seen as who I am.

I never really hated my body, including secondary sexual characteristics. I found sudden curves alien and curious, but not inherently un-me except that I turned invisible to others. They became confused about who I am and suddenly thought I was a woman. V bizarre.

I dressed "masc" as a tween, in various ways, in plays, at Halloween, shopping in the boys' section + menswear for some formal stuff. But at <5' & very hourglass + fem features, I never read as even androgynous to anyone. And it didn't actually help me match my internal self.

Watching the latest season of Sex Ed and having all sorts of enby flashbacks/questions. Remembering the first time I read about binding when I was a tween and how it really really clicked but also the people were hoping to prevent breast growth and it was too late for me.
